Clifford Brown nâ€™a vÃ©cu que jusquâ€™Ã  25 ans, mais quelques courtes annÃ©es lui ont suffi pour laisser une empreinte permanente sur le jazz. Il peut jouer lâ€™accompagnateur lyrique des chanteurs de love songs, puis se retourner et mener son groupe Ã  travers une composition dâ€™une complexitÃ© et dâ€™une originalitÃ© surprenante. Bien quâ€™il ne soit vivant , ses enregistrements restent un cadeau pour tous les Ã©tudiants passionnÃ©s de musique en gÃ©nÃ©ral et de jazz en particulier.

Clifford Brown lived only to 25, but a few short years were all he needed to leave a permanent mark on jazz. As a trumpeter, Brown is the complete package. His clean articulation never wavers, even at high speeds. He can play lyrical accompanist to torch singers, then turn around and lead his band through a composition of startling intricacy and originality. Thought he is gone, his recordings remain a gift to every dedicated student of music.

Titre: "Bodies in motion" at the Petit Palais
Chapeau: To mark the Paris 2024 Olympic and Paralympic Games, from May 15th, 2024 the Petit Palais is celebrating "Bodies in motion" (Le Corps en mouvement). An exhibition of artwork from the Petit Palais' collection that link art and sport.
Description:
Wrapped in Olympic colors, this exhibition features 50 art pieces from the Petit Palais, ranging from Antiquity to the early 20th century, some of which have been specially brought out of the museum's storage. The museum's paintings, sculptures, objects, drawings and prints have been selected for their focus on the body, anatomy and sport. The exhibition is divided into seven sections.


The tour begins in the Antiques gallery, which takes us back in time to the Origin of the Games. A little further on, the icons collection highlights the representation of the heroic body through the figure of Saint George slaying the dragon. Body drawings remind us of the importance of the human figure in Western art, the exposition presents studies of male nudes by DÃ¼rer and Rembrandt. The chronology then continues with a dance interlude around bodies suspended in motion. This particular selection of artwork shows that artists throughout the ages have been fascinated by dancing. They have always been eager to capture its essence, as Carpeaux did with his Trois GrÃ¢ces (The Three Graces).

The Body sculpture section sheds light on sculptors' quest for life within still pieces. With La Danseuse Sacha Lyo, Sergei Yurevich manages to capture the dancer's tense posture. The Saddle up! part addresses the emancipation of women through sport, with paintings by Jacques-Emile Blanche and LÃ©on Comerre. Bodies at play presents children's games such as battledore and shuttlecock or pick-up sticks, the respective ancestors of badminton and Mikado, through 18th-century paintings. The final section of the tour takes a look at sports in vogue at the beginning of the 20th century, marking the arrival of the modern Olympic Games. This new era then takes visitors right up to the present day. To mark the centenary of the Paris Olympics, the Petit Palais is showcasing two of FÃ©lix Bracquemond's vases which were awarded to sportsmen and women in 1924.
Nom du lieu: Petit Palais - MusÃ©e des beaux-arts de la Ville de Paris

Ã€ travers ce fonds photographique jamais prÃ©sentÃ© auparavant au musÃ©e des Arts dÃ©coratifs, le voile est levÃ© sur une pratique qui a marquÃ© le monde de la mode au dÃ©but du XXe siÃ¨cle et dont lâ€™objectif, celui de protÃ©ger les modÃ¨les de la contrefaÃ§on, reste dâ€™une actualitÃ© brulante, au regard des possibilitÃ©s offertes par la rÃ©volution digitale et lâ€™intelligence artificielle.

Leurs clichÃ©s, souvent flous, pris de loin, pas toujours cadrÃ©s, tÃ©moignent de lâ€™exaltation dâ€™un moment quâ€™ils savent historique. Titre: Fashion in motion nÂ°2, at the Palais Galliera
Chapeau: From April 26th, 2024 to January 5th, 2025, the Palais Galliera hosts Fashion in Motion #2 (La mode en mouvement #2). With over 250 new works presented in this second show, the exhibition retraces the history of fashion from the 18th century to the present day through the museum's collections, and showcases the transversal theme of bodies in motion. There is also a focus on the seaside, that reveals rare pieces to the public.
Description:
With Paris hosting the Olympic and Paralympic Games in summer 2024, La Mode en mouvement #2 (Fashion in motion #2) takes a look at the history of sports clothing, going through to the social consequences of its evolution.

Clothing designed for sport (horse riding, tennis, golf, cyclingâ€¦) is heavily contrasted with streetwear. This second presentation allows the public to appreciate the gradual specialization of sportswear, as well as the introduction of sportswear into the everyday wardrobe.

The BalnÃ©aire (seaside) section focuses on sea bathing and swimming, symbols of the expansion of sporting activities from the late 19th century onward. This is an opportunity to discover the extensive collection of bathing suits, swimwear, beachwear and accessories housed at the Palais Galliera. This section highlights the changing relationship towards the body and the evolution of its perception in public, as well as the notion of modesty and decency. It also reveals changes in beauty and aesthetic canon, notably through our relationship with tanning.

La Mode en mouvement #2 benefits from exceptional loans from the MusÃ©e national du Sport (Nice), the Fondation Azzedine AlaÃ¯a, the BibliothÃ¨que Forney (Paris), the BibliothÃ¨que historique de la Ville de Paris, the MusÃ©e Carnavalet - Histoire de Paris, the CHANEL Heritage Collection, the Ã‰mile HermÃ¨s Collection and the Yohji Yamamoto House. These works put the Palais Galliera's exhibits into perspective and bear witness to the practice of physical and sporting activities through the ages, both leisurely and competitively.

This exhibition has been awarded the "Cultural Olympiad " certificate. An associated multidisciplinary cultural program will be set up in connection with the 2024 Olympic and Paralympic Games.
Nom du lieu: Square du Palais Galliera - MusÃ©e de la Mode de la Ville de Paris

Du 7 avril aÌ€ la mi-juillet 1994 sur les collines du Rwanda, plus dâ€™un million dâ€™hommes, de femmes et dâ€™enfants tutsi peÌrirent au nom dâ€™une utopie politique visant aÌ€ refonder la pureteÌ raciale dâ€™une nation hutu deÌbarrasseÌe dâ€™une minoriteÌ deÌpeinte comme sournoise et nuisible. Produit de lâ€™histoire longue de notre tragique xxe sieÌ€cle, il a reÌpondu aÌ€ des logiques politiques preÌcises, elles-meÌ‚mes adosseÌes aÌ€ une ideÌologie raciste inscrite dans le passeÌ colonial et post-colonial du Rwanda.

Ce projet mâ€™a donneÌ de la force, une certitude de ce que je voulais faire ou non, mais mâ€™a aussi apporteÌ une forme de pression parce que je doute beaucoup.Â Â» Chez elle, la musique sert sans cesse aÌ€ reÌpondre aÌ€ des questionnements. Titre: Â«Â Speaking StonesÂ : l'art rupestre du LadakhÂ Â» Exposition et Rencontre avec Ahtushi Deshpande
Chapeau: La mÃ©diathÃ¨que prÃ©sente le travail de la photographe indienne Ahtushi Deshpande du 13 novembre 2024 au 5 janvier 2025. Vernissage le mercredi 13/11 Ã  18h et une rencontre bilingue avec la photographe le samedi 16 novembre Ã  15h.
Description:
L'art rupestre du Ladakh, une rÃ©gion himalayenne du nord-ouest de lâ€™Inde, permet de comprendre le peuplement de cette rÃ©gion de haute altitude sur le long terme, de 3Â 000 avant notre Ã¨re Ã  1200 de notre Ã¨re. Ahtushi Deshpande, journaliste et photographe indienne, a parcouru cette rÃ©gion pendant plus de dix ans. En utilisant des techniques de photographie spÃ©cifiques, elle parvient Ã  montrer l'art millÃ©naire des roches gravÃ©es sous un jour artistique nouveau, en dÃ©voilant un vÃ©ritable musÃ©e Ã  ciel ouvert. Ã€ travers son ouvrage Â«Â Speaking StonesÂ : Rock Art of LadakhÂ Â» publiÃ© en Inde tout rÃ©cemment et sÃ©lectionnÃ© au Prix international du Livre de montagne de Banff 2024, elle souhaite sensibiliser le public Ã  ce patrimoine exceptionnel.

Selon Ahtushi, Â«Â Cette exposition vous invite Ã  un voyage Ã  travers les conversations silencieuses entre l'humanitÃ© et la nature. Elle montre comment les anciens pÃ©troglyphes, gravÃ©s dans la pierre, reflÃ¨tent notre lien profond avec le monde naturel et les premiers systÃ¨mes de croyance. Ã€ travers ces Å“uvres d'art intemporelles, les thÃ¨mes de la rÃ©silience, de la mÃ©moire et du passage du temps prennent vie, offrant une fenÃªtre sur notre histoire commune.Â Â» www.ahtushi.com

_

Cette exposition se tient dans le cadre d'un programme de recherches sur l'archÃ©ologie de lâ€™Himalaya, portÃ© par l'Ã‰cole Pratique des Hautes Etudes, accueilli par le Centre de Recherche sur les Civilisations de l'Asie Orientale et soutenu par la Ville de Paris dans le cadre du dispositif Emergence(s).

Vernissage le mercredi 13 novembre Ã  18h.

Rencontre bilingue le samedi 16 novembre Ã  15h (rÃ©servÃ©e conseillÃ©e).

From November 13, 2024 to January 5, 2025, the mediatheque will be hosting the exhibition "Speaking Stones: Rock Art of Ladakh" by Indian photographer Ahtushi Deshpande. A bilingual meeting will take place on Saturday November 16 at 3pm.

The rock art of Ladakh, a Himalayan region in north-west India, provides an insight into the long-term settlement of this high-altitude region, from 3000 BC to 1200 AD. Ahtushi Deshpande, an Indian journalist and photographer, has spent more than ten years in this region. Using specific photographic techniques, she has succeeded in showing the age-old art of engraved rocks in a new artistic light, revealing a veritable open-air museum. Through her book Â«Â Speaking StonesÂ : Rock Art of LadakhÂ Â», recently published in India and selected for the international Banff Mountain Book Award 2024 , she aims to raise public awareness of this exceptional heritage.

According to Ahtushi, Â«Â This exhibition invites you to embark on a journey through the silent conversations between humanity and nature. It dwelves into how ancient petroglyphs, carved into stone, mirror our profound connection with the natural world and early belief systems. Through these timeless artworks, themes of resilience, memory, and the passage of time come to life, offering a window into our shared history.Â Â» www.ahtushi.com

_

This exhibition is part of a research program on the archaeology of the Himalayas, organized by the Ã‰cole Pratique des Hautes Etudes (EPHE), hosted by the Centre de Recherche sur les Civilisations de l'Asie Orientale (CRCAO) and supported by the City of Paris as part of the Emergence(s) program.

Reservations recommended for the bilingual meeting on Saturday November 16 at 3pm.

Cette reconnaissance - ultime eÌtape du travail commenceÌ par Serge Klarsfeld pour eÌtablir une liste des fusilleÌs -, conduite avec le soutien du secreÌtariat dâ€™EÌtat aupreÌ€s du ministre des ArmeÌes chargeÌ des anciens combattants et de la meÌmoire, a permis une modification des conditions dâ€™attributions de cette mention et a ouvert un large champ de recherches.

En preÌsence de Serge Klarsfeld, avocat, historien, fondateur de lâ€™association Fils et Filles des deÌporteÌs juifs de France, Marion VeyssieÌ€re, conseilleÌ€re culture et patrimoine au cabinet de la ministre deÌleÌgueÌe aupreÌ€s de la ministre des ArmeÌes, chargeÌe de la meÌmoire et des anciens combattants (sous reÌserve) et Jeanâ€Baptiste Romain, directeur des Hauts Lieux de la meÌmoire en IÌ‚le-de- France, ONaCVG.

AnimeÌ par Claude Bochurberg, journaliste de la meÌmoire.

Quand Jean Dubuffet crÃ©e sa fondation, il a dâ€™abord dans lâ€™esprit de prÃ©server deux de ses rÃ©alisations terminÃ©es dans lâ€™annÃ©eÂ : la Closerie Falbala Ã  PÃ©rigny-sur-Yerres et les Ã©lÃ©ments de son spectacle Coucou Bazar, produit rÃ©cemment Ã  New York et Paris. Si ces deux Å“uvres uniques font naturellement partie de la dotation initiale, Dubuffet, soucieux de lâ€™avenir de sa fondation, va la doter de toutes ses maquettes dâ€™architecture et projets de monuments afin de lui permettre de rÃ©aliser des sculptures pour des collections privÃ©es, des institutions ou des lieux publics. Rares aussi sont les artistes qui ont, de leur vivant, entrepris dâ€™organiser leurs propres archives.
